greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = sum of positive divisors k of n with k <= sqrt(n).
comment: Row sums of the table in A161906. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 08 2013

Conjecture: a(n) is the total number of parts in all partitions of n into consecutive parts that differ by 2. - _Omar E. Pol_, May 03 2020. This conjecture is true (the g.f. for these partitions agrees with the g.f. given below by _Michael Somos_). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 02 2020
Column 2 of A334466. - _Omar E. Pol_, Dec 03 2020
link: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Douglas E. Iannucci, On sums of the small divisors of a natural number, arXiv:1910.11835 [math.NT], 2019.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i=1..floor(sqrt(n))} (-(n mod i) + (n-1) mod i + 1). - _José de Jesús Camacho Medina_, Feb 21 2021
example: a(9) = 4 = 1 + 3 because 1 and 3 are the positive divisors of 9 that are <= sqrt(9).
maple: with(numtheory):for n from 1 to 200 do c[n] := 0:d := divisors(n):for i from 1 to nops(d) do if d[i]<=n^.5+10^(-10) then c[n] := c[n]+d[i]:fi:od:od:seq(c[i],i=1..200);
mathematica: f[n_] := Plus @@ Select[ Divisors@n, # <= Sqrt@n &]; Array[f, 94] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Mar 04 2010 *)
program: (PARI) { for (n=1, 1000, d=divisors(n); s=sum(k=1, ceil(length(d)/2), d[k]); write("b066839.txt", n, " ", s) ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Mar 31 2010
(Sage) [sum(k for k in divisors(n) if k^2<=n) for n in (1..94)] # _Giuseppe Coppoletta_, Jan 21 2015
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Jan 20 2002
ext: More terms from Larry Reeves (larryr(AT)acm.org), Apr 12 2002
